metadata.title: Pick Your Mopar Wing Car
metadata.description: These one-off cars are both sanctioned by Mopar and Chrysler.
metadata.author: Steven Symes

metadata.title: Own Two Concept 1971 Muscle Cars That Should Have Been
metadata.description: Two one-of-a-kind American muscle concepts brought to life thanks to secret wind tunnel testing.
metadata.author: Amie Williams

sections: Here are two chances to own a one-of-a-kind '71 Mopar.
Most Mopar muscle cars from '60s and '70s were rare to begin with, but
has a pair of custom one-off creations for the ultimate Mopar collector. For open-air enthusiasts, there is the
, while restomod lovers can check out this modernized
. Either way, these cars will definitely turn heads.

The 1971 Dodge Charger SRT Serpent is what you get if you cross a '71 Charger with a '69 Charger Daytona AND an early third-gen Dodge Challenger SRT8. Under the hood, is a 600-horsepower, 6.1-liter Hemi V8 with a custom 3x3 electronic fuel injection system making it a modern version of a six-pack Hemi, and this engine is matched with a six-speed manual transmission. The exterior has been modified with hidden headlights that get a modern touch with LED halo rings, while the raised rear wing and Snakeskin Green paint job (from the Dodge Viper) will certainly make this car an instant hit at car shows.

While the Charger SRT Serpent is a fully custom restomod, this 1971 Plymouth GTX Convertible XCON Concept might fool all but the most serious classic car enthusiasts. Plymouth never built a version of GTX in its final year, but this Curious Yellow GTX drop top will have Mopar fanatics doing a double take. The car itself underwent a nut-and-bolt rotisserie restoration, and the convertible conversion features an OE stock replaceable vinyl top.
Both of these custom Mopar creations are currently up for sale through Rev Muscle Cars, and while pricing hasn't been announced,
for more info on these cars or any of the other amazing classic and collector cars that are listed for sale.
